# Create function to pull data from the Dedicated SQL Pool
def QueryDataSQLPool (query):
    # Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
    # Database can be specified as a Spark Config or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
    spark.conf.set("spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database", "SQLPoolTest")

    # Read from a query
    # Query can be provided either as an argument to synapsesql or as a Constant - Constants.QUERY
    df = (spark.read
                        # Name of the SQL Dedicated Pool or database where to run the query
                        # Database can be specified as a Spark Config - spark.sqlanalyticsconnector.dw.database or as a Constant - Constants.DATABASE
                        .option(Constants.DATABASE, "SQLPoolTest")
                        # If `Constants.SERVER` is not provided, the `<database_name>` from the three-part table name argument
                        # to `synapsesql` method is used to infer the Synapse Dedicated SQL End Point.
                        .option(Constants.SERVER, "pendragon-synapse.sql.azuresynapse.net")
                        # Defaults to storage path defined in the runtime configurations
                        .option(Constants.TEMP_FOLDER, "abfss://pendragon@pendragon.dfs.core.windows.net/NotebookStaging")
                        # query from which data will be read
                        .option(Constants.QUERY, query)
                        .synapsesql()
    )
    return(df)

# Define a UDF (user-defined function) to apply the regular expressions and stop words removal to each row of the dataframe
def clean_text(text):
    # Remove URLs, hashtags, mentions, and emojis using regular expressions
    text = re.sub(url_regex, '', text)
    text = re.sub(hashtag_regex, '', text)
    text = re.sub(mention_regex, '', text)
    text = re.sub(emoji_regex, '', text)

    # Remove special characters
    text = re.sub(special_chars_regex, '', text)

    return text

import nltk

from nltk.corpus import stopwords
nltk.download('stopwords')

# Define a function to clean the text
def clean_text1(text):
    # Convert text to lowercase
    text = text.lower()
    # Remove URLs
    text = re.sub(r'http\S+', '', text)
    # Remove mentions and hashtags
    text = re.sub(r'@\w+|#\w+', '', text)
    # Remove special characters
    text = re.sub(r'[^\w\s]', '', text)
    # Tokenize the text
    tokens = nltk.word_tokenize(text)
    # Remove stop words
    stopwords_list = stopwords.words('english')
    tokens = [token for token in tokens if token not in stopwords_list]
    # Remove any remaining noise
    tokens = [re.sub(r'[^\w\s]', '', token) for token in tokens]
    return ' '.join(tokens)

# Define a UDF to apply the clean_text function

def authenticate_client():

# Creat function to apply Exractive Summarization
def sample_extractive_summarization(client,doc):

    document = doc

    poller = client.begin_analyze_actions(
        document,
        actions=[
            ExtractSummaryAction(max_sentence_count=10)
        ],
    )
    document_results = poller.result()
    for result in document_results:
        extract_summary_result = result[0]  # first document, first result
        #if extract_summary_result.is_error:
        #    print("...Is an error with code '{}' and message '{}'".format(
        #        extract_summary_result.code, extract_summary_result.message
        #    ))
        #else:
            #print("Summary extracted: \n{}".format(
            #    " ".join([sentence.text for sentence in extract_summary_result.sentences]))
            #)
    return(" ".join([sentence.text for sentence in extract_summary_result.sentences]))

# Define dataframe schema
schema = StructType([
    StructField("topic", ShortType(), True),
    StructField("abstractive_summary", StringType(), True)
# Cognitive Services Extractive to OpenAI Abstractive Summarization

def Abstractive_Summarization(dataframe, topic):
    # Apply the UDF to the 'text' column of the dataframe and store the result in a new column named 'cleanText'
    df = dataframe.withColumn('cleanText', clean_text_udf('text'))
    # Apply the UDF1 to a DataFrame column
    df = df.withColumn('cleanText', clean_text1_udf('cleanText'))
    
    # Remove empty spaces equal to or bigger than 2 spaces
    df = df.withColumn('text_trimmed', regexp_replace(df['cleanText'], '\s{2,}', ' '))
    # Remove empty spaces before and after text.
    df = df.withColumn('text_trimmed', trim(df['text_trimmed']))
    text_col = df.select('text_trimmed')
    # Collect all tweets into a list
    text_list = text_col.rdd.map(lambda row: row[0]).collect()
    # Join all tweets into a single document
    result = " ".join([text + "." for text in text_list])
    document = [result]
    # Extract the string that contains all tweets
    input_string = document[0]

    # Split the string into batches of 125000 characters maximum
    max_chars_per_batch = 125000
    result = split_into_batches(input_string, max_chars_per_batch)
    print('Number of batches',len(result))
    for batch in result:
        print('Characters in batch', len(batch))

    # For each batch create an extractive summary of 10 sentences
    ex_summaries = []

    for each in result:
        #print('Batch', [each])
        ex_summary = sample_extractive_summarization(client,[each])
        ex_summaries.append([ex_summary])

    print('All Extractive Summaries', ex_summaries) 

    ab_summaries = []

    retries = 3
    delay = 300

    for i in range(retries):
        try:
            # Create a list of abstractive summaries for each extractive summary
            for each in ex_summaries:
                print(each)
                print(each[0])
                print(type(each[0]))
                p = 'Provide a summary of the text below that captures its main idea.\n\n' + each[0] 
                print(p)

                response = openai.Completion.create(
                engine="SummaryDivinci003",
                prompt = p,
                temperature=0.3,
                max_tokens=250,
                top_p=1,
                frequency_penalty=0,
                presence_penalty=0,
                best_of=1,
                stop=None)

                print(response['choices'][0]['text'])

                ab_summaries.append(response['choices'][0]['text'])
                if len(ex_summaries) > 1:
                    time.sleep(10)
            print(ab_summaries)
            print("Code succeeded!")
            break # Break out of the loop if code succeeds
        except:
            time.sleep(delay)
            print('Failed')
            #raise Exception(f"Failed after {retries} retries")
            ab_summaries = []

    else:
        raise Exception(f"Failed after {retries} retries")

    # Wait 10 seconds
    time.sleep(10)

    # Create one abstractive summary using the collection of abstractive summaries created above
    p = 'Provide a summary of the text below that captures the main idea. ' + ''.join(ab_summaries)

    response = openai.Completion.create(
    engine="SummaryDivinci003",
    prompt = p,
    temperature=0.3,
    max_tokens=250,
    top_p=1,
    frequency_penalty=0,
    presence_penalty=0,
    best_of=1,
    stop=None)
 
    final_ab_summarization = response['choices'][0]['text']
    #print(response['choices'][0]['text'])
    print('-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------')
    print('Abstractive Summary: ', final_ab_summarization)
    print('Character Length:', len(final_ab_summarization))

    # Put the meta abstractive summary into a data frame and return the data frame object 
    return(spark.createDataFrame([(topic, final_ab_summarization)], schema))
